Peter Dutton, the defence minister, described the Victorian proposal as smoke and mirrors and yet now it would appear the government is putting some effort into giving a proper assessment to the Victorian proposal. Last night, we heard from the health department that they had not even been asked to assess the Toowoomba proposal ... the prime minister in particular [needs to realise] it is not his job to sit back and wait for proposals to come forward. The Commonwealth is responsible for quarantine and they have received advice after advice or purpose-built facilities. The former Victorian premier Jeff Kennett has said we need to other facilities in addition to Alice Springs. They should be seeking proposals for a network of facilities to take the pressure off our hotel system which is leaking the virus almost on a weekly and fortnightly basis and was built for tourism purposes. Liberal senator Dean Smith opens his questions to Brendan Murphy with: Professor Murphy, the virus doesn‚Äôt sleep, I presume? Murphy laughs and says ‚Äòno‚Äô. Smith is now outlining the ‚Äúenormity of the exercise‚Äù Murphy and health officials have had in ‚Äúkeeping this country safe,‚Äù including Murphy going back to the office to answer emails after he finished his estimates appearance at 11pm. Smith thanks him and the department for their work. ‚ÄúThe arguments and discussions we are having are around the fringes of the issues,‚Äù Smith says. Labor senator Murray Watt says everyone is grateful, but it is still the job of estimates to ask questions about things which have gone well and things which have not gone so well. So, that‚Äôs settled. Everyone is grateful for the job officials have done, but there are still things which have gone not as well as they could have, and that should be questioned. Labor MP Clare O‚ÄôNeil was a guest on RN Breakfast this morning, where she was asked by Hamish Macdonald why Victoria ‚Äòcan‚Äôt seem to get on top of outbreaks‚Äô like other states. Her answer has caused a little flurry on social media, after she compared movement in Sydney and Melbourne. I‚Äòm in lockdown in my home in Victoria, right now. It feels like a little bit of an unfair question and we‚Äôve got to remember that this outbreak actually came through a leak from South Australian quarantine. You would have heard a number of epidemiologists answering the question that you‚Äôve just asked me over previous days and so I don‚Äôt want to get into the science too deeply as that‚Äôs really their role. But, I think, they‚Äôve referred to a bunch of specific things about Victoria - the layout of the city, for example, is one where people move around a lot more than they do versus Sydney, for example, where people tend to stay within their suburbs or their regions. But, the most important thing that‚Äôs happening right now in Victoria, Hamish, is that we are dealing with a much more contagious form of Covid than we‚Äôve seen in any previous outbreaks. You mentioned, in your opener there, that we‚Äôve had situations in Victoria where people have caught Covid from one another by brushing past one another in a store. This has never happened before in a Covid outbreak and I personally am glad that the Victorian government‚Äôs being pretty conservative. We‚Äôll get on to aged care in a minute but we know, through bitter, bitter experience, the agony that can be caused when we don‚Äôt get on top of outbreaks and we‚Äôre proud as Victorians that we‚Äôre working together as a community to protect people that are vulnerable. At least in my feed, Sydney residents seem incensed at being described as dwelling in the suburbs a little more. But an epidemiologist did say it: The Greens senator Rachel Siewert is questioning Professor Brendan Murphy why ventilation is not in the guidelines for quarantine. Murphy says the states and territories are looking at it, but it is not in the guidelines, because it‚Äôs a building and engineering process. Siewert says that is ‚Äòsemantics‚Äô. Murphy says CMO Professor Paul Kelly will be able to answer more of those questions later this afternoon. So things are going well then. For those asking, we learnt yesterday that Victoria doesn‚Äôt give any information to its federal counterparts until it has sent out its tweet with the daily numbers. That is something that happened during the second outbreak. Once the numbers are out, Victorian authorities, through their usual departmental channels, share the information with other health authorities. It‚Äôs part of the information share that lets each jurisdiction know what is happening, so they can make their own decisions regarding health orders and borders. Brendan Murphy is the head of the federal health department and he is facing estimates today ‚Äì it is only normal he would receive the information, and when asked in estimates, he is sharing that information. Over in health estimates, Prof Brendan Murphy has given a little more information about the six new Victorian cases. Five are linked to known cases, he says, while the sixth is the person NSW Health put an alert out about last night. As we wait on the Victorian press conference, which is likely to confirm an extension of the lockdown, please keep in mind the thousands of people who have lost a week‚Äôs pay with no warning, and are on the cusp of losing another. As late as yesterday afternoon, federal Liberal party MPs were arguing it was the job of the Victorian government to provide financial support if it extended the lockdown, pointing to lockdowns in WA and Queensland, which have occurred with no jobkeeper assistance. But both were much, much shorter. Three days is one thing - and it is hard enough. A week can be devastating. Anything longer than that, and you risk your whole life falling apart. Not everyone has the bank of mum and dad to fall back on. Not everyone has savings. Not everyone can just ‚Äògo a week‚Äô without pay. The uncertainty so many people must be facing right now is heartbreaking. This is some more good news. Mike Bowers has been out and about this morning. The department of health is in front of senate estimates today ‚Äì with quarantine the topic of the morning hearings. Last night, estimates heard there had been 21 breaches of hotel quarantine. It was a hotel quarantine breach in Adelaide which sparked the most recent Victorian lockdown. Jane Halton, who (among many, many other reviews) was handed the job of reviewing Australia‚Äôs hotel quarantine system, was asked on ABC radio RN this morning how she thought quarantine was going. She was fairly plain spoken: Well, I‚Äôm disappointed that it certainly appears that we don‚Äôt have continual adoption of best practice right across the system. One of the things I talked about in October last year is the need to make sure best practice is adopted. And as we‚Äôve discussed before, this virus is not staying still waiting for us to catch up with it and get in front of it, the virus continues to change. That means our systems need to continue to adapt. And certainly, as it‚Äôs been reported, some of the breaches we have seen recently are a direct reflection of an absence of best practice in some of these systems. So to say that I‚Äôm disappointed about that I think is the minimum, I would say. Halton said while she welcomed the expansion of the Howard Springs dedicated quarantine facility, she also found it ‚Äúa bit perplexing that it‚Äôs taken us this long‚Äù. Halton had recommended national quarantine facilities, purpose built to handle the job. She doesn‚Äôt care where they are - as long as they are built to purpose. I‚Äôm not wedded to one particular location over another. I think the style of quarantine that we‚Äôre talking about here is what‚Äôs important. And having that as a significant component of our quarantine program is certainly desirable. And that‚Äôs what I talked about. The interview finished with this: Hamish Macdonald: I know you‚Äôre someone who in Canberra has been known to be frank. Would your frank and fearless advice to government now be, ‚ÄòAlright, pull your socks up, get on with this‚Äô? Halton: Certainly, that is my advice. That we should be getting on with this as a priority. Definitely. The numbers are in. These six new cases bring the total number associated with this outbreak to 60. More than 51,000 tests though, and 20,500 vaccinations. That‚Äôs incredible, Victoria. In defending the federal government for not vaccinating aged care workers (in June), a group of people who were meant to be in the priority 1A group, Queensland senator Matt Canavan attacked the Queensland Labor government for not immediately vaccinating health care workers months ago. (The Queensland government, like Victoria, is launching its own vaccination blitz to speed up the vaccination roll out for aged and disability care workers) Canavan told the Nine Network: This is from the government only a few months ago had failed to vaccinate their frontline workers and partly led to the Brisbane outbreak. It‚Äôs a bit hypocritical for them to be throwing mud about aged care centres when they didn‚Äôt do the same in their own hospitals just a few months ago. Queensland is also the state with the lowest utilisation rate of the vaccines. They‚Äôve never properly explained why they‚Äôve only used 64% of their vaccines when Victoria and NSW are 80%. Maybe Queensland will finally start using its vaccines, that will be a positive. For reasons unknown to anyone, members of the federal government continue to argue over whether or not the vaccine roll out is ‚Äúa race‚Äù. Here was Dan Tehan on the Seven Network this morning: If it was a race, how would you handicap at? Let‚Äôs get serious about this. It is a rollout, I can tell you I‚Äôll be having my second vaccination this week and I say to all Australians listening to the show, go up, get vaccinated. That‚Äôs the best thing all of us can do. Labor has announced a new ‚Äòyouth engagement‚Äô model: If elected, an Albanese Labor government will:- Establish a framework to directly and formally engage with young Australians on an ongoing basis. Establish an Office for Youth so that, rather than youth engagement being an afterthought or duplicating functions across departments, there is a dedicated unit within government to feed in the contribution from young people and advocates, improve and harmonise policy across government, and ensure government is communicating effectively with young people. Commit to a Minister for Youth to improve and facilitate a holistic response across portfolios on issues affecting young Australians. The ABC has reported the crew member who tested positive to Covid and was removed from a freight ship docked in WA has now tested negative. He is thought to be a historical case. We are all still waiting on official confirmation of today‚Äôs results (as well as official word on the lockdown being extended) but this is hopefully some good news. It being June means Mathias Cormann is officially the OECD head. As part of his maiden speech Cormann, apparently a huge fan of the Paris agreement now, said: Across the OECD‚Äôs diverse membership, different countries and regions around the world have different opportunities to make the strongest possible contribution to our collective emissions reduction outcomes and the net-zero emissions target locked into the Paris Agreement. We all face similar transition challenges and can all agree that effective global action on climate change is a must and we must get to zero net emissions as soon as possible. Climate policy responses will increasingly need to factor into long-term planning. Economic recovery efforts to Covid-19 are a key opportunity to target support towards investments that drive the development and commercialisation of new technologies. Through the OECD, we can come together to share ideas about our collective green recovery effort on our journey towards a low emissions future. As Secretary-General I will strive to make the OECD a place that inspires collaboration and action in support of a sustainable future. We start today with NSW authorities worried about potential for Covid to have spread, after a Melbourne traveller was potentially infectious while on holiday. The reason for the worry is because of the highly contagious nature of this variant of Covid. Victorian authorities have spoken about how they are seeing more stranger to stranger transmission with this variant. It‚Äôs not just spending time with people which can spread the virus, it could be passing them in a small store. Hence the worry. We‚Äôll be keeping an eye on that today, and will bring you all the Victorian news as we wait to see whether or not the lockdown will be lifted. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs not looking overly positive at the moment, with all signs pointing to the lockdown being extended beyond Thursday. There are still a lot of primary and secondary contacts in isolation and the list of exposure sites sits at more than 500. We‚Äôll bring you the news as soon as we know for sure. Parliament and estimates continues today as well. Richard Colbeck, the aged care minister, didn‚Äôt have the best day yesterday, as he struggled to answer simple questions like ‚Äòwho is responsible for vaccinating aged care workers‚Äô. Then there was some friendly fire, with Amanda Stoker, a Liberal senator, questioning James McGrath, also a Liberal senator, over what questions he was allowing as chair of the committee. McGrath beat Stoker to the number one spot on the Queensland ticket, leaving Stoker at number three (winnable, but not guaranteed). We‚Äôll bring you all the day‚Äôs events. You have Mike Bowers with you as always, taking you into the parliament, with Katharine Murphy, Paul Karp, Daniel Hurst and Sarah Martin keeping you updated on what‚Äôs happening around parliament. It being a sitting day, you‚Äôll have Amy Remeikis on the blog for most of the day. I just had chocolate cake for breakfast so it‚Äôs going to be great. Ready?

headline: Richard Colbeck can no longer pass the buck on the failure to protect Australians in aged care homes
standfirst: Sooner or later, he will need to take responsibility for all the heartbreaking tragedies that have occurred on his watch
trailText: Sooner or later, he will need to take responsibility for all the heartbreaking tragedies that have occurred on his watch
body:
With Richard Colbeck as the federal aged care minister, 685 Australians in aged care homes have died from Covid. Is he asleep at the wheel? Colbeck‚Äôs lack of leadership since Covid emerged is now putting even more lives at risk by allowing staff to work at multiple aged care homes without residents and staff being vaccinated. Meanwhile, Colbeck has indicated he has no intention of resigning.

If the stakes weren‚Äôt so dreadfully high, Colbeck‚Äôs position would be comic. In a Senate estimates hearing in October, he said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel responsible personally for the deaths that have occurred, as tragic as they are, which were caused by Covid-19.‚Äù

Related: Richard Colbeck admits not knowing how many aged care workers have been vaccinated

How could he not feel responsible? Colbeck had advanced warning of the devastating impact that Covid-19 could wreak. It was clear he needed to prepare the private aged care sector for community transmission. Evidence from around the world showed Covid spread like wildfire in residential aged care settings.

At a Senate inquiry last year, Colbeck was also unable to recall how many residents had died during the pandemic.

During Colbeck‚Äôs tenure as aged care minister, deaths in aged care homes account for 74.6% of all deaths from Covid-19 in Australia according to a Senate inquiry report. This is one of the world‚Äôs highest rates of deaths in residential aged care as a proportion of total Covid-19 deaths.

Older people who died of Covid were partners, siblings, parents, grandparents, uncles, aunts and friends. Their deaths highlighted the systemic failures in the aged care sector and the federal government‚Äôs lack of planning for community transmission during the pandemic.

The federal government also did not have a specific pandemic plan for the aged care sector, a fact confirmed by the royal commission into aged care quality and safety. In response, Colbeck stated: ‚ÄúThe government maintains its position that it has a plan in place.‚Äù

What the minister may have been referring to was the Department of Health‚Äôs 7th edition of the updated national Covid-19 aged care plan. Another great marketing trick from the prime minister‚Äôs playbook ‚Äì give the impression there were six earlier editions of the aged care plan when in fact there were none.

Instead of taking responsibility for their failure to protect residents in aged care homes, federal health minister Greg Hunt, Scott Morrison and Colbeck indulged in semantics and repeatedly attempted to shift the blame.

When asked about the federal responsibility for aged care in August, Morrison responded in a word salad: ‚ÄúWell public health, we regulate aged care, but when there is a public health pandemic, then public health, which, whether it gets into aged care, shopping centres, schools or anywhere else, then they are things that are matters for Victoria. So I don‚Äôt think that it is as binary as you suggest.‚Äù

Which brings us to the vaccination rollout in private aged care homes. Rather than rely on the structures used to successfully administer the annual flu vaccine to residents, the federal government outsourced the vaccination rollout to private companies. Aspen Medical, Health Care Australia, Sonic Healthcare and International SOS have received $76m for this work, according to Department of Health associate secretary Caroline Edwards.

On 16 February, Hunt announced: ‚ÄúIn the coming weeks, the vaccination program will reach more than 2,600 residential aged care facilities, more than 183,000 residents and 339,000 staff.‚Äù A few days later, Morrison said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre ready to go ‚Ä¶ We have been preparing, we have been planning, we have been dotting the Is and crossing the Ts.‚Äù

Despite these vacuous announcements, the vaccination rollout has been an unmitigated disaster. More than three months after Hunt‚Äôs announcement, about 30% of aged care homes have not received their second dose. Colbeck said some homes had ‚Äúchosen‚Äù to delay their vaccination, a claim challenged by operators of unvaccinated aged care homes in Melbourne.

And who knows how many staff have been vaccinated? Even Colbeck admits he doesn‚Äôt know because the government has not been collecting the data.

Aged care staff were supposed to be a priority in the vaccine rollout. Yet the vaccination workforce was contracted to vaccinate residents but not staff. Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation Victorian branch secretary Lisa Fitzpatrick said from the beginning of the rollout staff had only received a jab from visiting medical staff if there were leftovers. So who is responsible for vaccinating staff in private aged care homes?

According to the Department of Health fact sheet for staff, the ‚Äúpriority is to deliver choice and flexibility for aged care staff to receive a Covid-19 vaccination as quickly as possible in the safest way‚Äù. ‚ÄúChoice and flexibility‚Äù is actually code for staff having to make their own appointments at a GP clinic or a state run vaccination site.

Related: ‚ÄòA dog‚Äôs breakfast‚Äô: where the Australian government went wrong with its aged care Covid response

Let‚Äôs be clear: the only way to ensure residents in aged care homes are protected against Covid is to make sure residents and staff are vaccinated. Yet a recent survey shows only 11% of the aged care workforce have been vaccinated.

Colbeck cannot pass the buck. He is responsible for this failure.

Colbeck is also responsible for staff working in multiple aged care homes when neither residents nor staff have been vaccinated. Just putting out guidelines does not stop aged care workers working in multiple aged care homes.

This has now resulted in residents in Victoria once again being in lockdown, with some confined to their room. These lockdowns are profoundly damaging to residents‚Äô mental and physical wellbeing. Some have argued they could also be illegal for false imprisonment.

Make no mistake: aged care homes are in lockdown in Victoria because Colbeck failed to deliver a successful vaccination rollout. While he says he is ‚Äúvery comfortable‚Äù with the vaccination rollout in aged care homes, many families in Victoria are extremely worried their loved one may test positive.

The horror story in aged care homes could have been prevented if Colbeck had tackled the systemic failures in the aged care sector. Instead, he just keeps kicking the can down the road and pouring money into a dysfunctional system.

Sooner or later Colbeck will need to take responsibility for all the heart-breaking tragedies and stuff ups that have occurred on his watch.

headline: Netball is stronger for social media revolution but it comes at a cost
standfirst: Fan engagement is improving but England international Jo Harten experienced the darker side of increased visibility this week
trailText: Fan engagement is improving but England international Jo Harten experienced the darker side of increased visibility this week
body:
It is a widely accepted fact in the sports media that while all sports are equal, some are more equal than others. That men‚Äôs sport receives greater coverage and attention is completely down to merit, to the demands of the audience. Over the last few years however, the women‚Äôs sport revolution has been quietly, yet confidently, breaking down these norms, due in a large part to the rise of social media.

No longer are the morning newspapers and nightly news bulletins the arbiters of what is newsworthy and interesting to sports fans. Social media has created a space where clubs and athletes can tell their own stories, build their own fanbases and prove their value.

Related: The best debut in netball history? Vixens reap rewards of late call-up | Erin Delahunty

For netball in particular, this has been revolutionary. As the only professional sport in Australia that is not tied to an equivalent men‚Äôs competition, it has long struggled to carve out a place for itself in the media. Increasingly, netball fans are doing it for them ‚Äì forming communities and sparking creativity. While official social media channels in netball are improving their engagement rapidly, the inspiration has come from the grass roots of the fandom.

At the forefront is Emma Blair, known as @conciergemaree on social media, who has reached legions of netball fans, players and commentators through her engaging use of TikTok. From light-hearted parodies of Suncorp Super Netball players and coaches through to the trials and tribulations of community netball, Blair has captured the spirit of the game in a way that has long eluded those paid to promote it. She effortlessly straddles the line between professional and grassroots, bringing the two together in a highly captivating manner that has created the perfect blueprint for administrators trying to convert the sport‚Äôs huge participation base into TV viewing figures.

But a revolution is never as straightforward as it seems and while fan engagement is improving, with that comes the darker side of increased visibility. Giants captain and England international Jo Harten experienced the drawbacks of social media after her team‚Äôs one-goal loss to the West Coast Fever on Monday night. After spending five days in Western Australia, unable to leave their hotel aside from one hour of training each day, Harten and her team played out an extraordinarily exciting game in front of a parochial Perth crowd, with the Fever taking the win from a penalty after the final whistle. Harten returned to her hotel room to discover a series of hateful, abusive messages sent to her on Instagram, urging her to ‚Äúdie‚Äù and ‚Äúrot in hell‚Äù and calling her an ‚Äúugly bitch‚Äù.

Harten posted the messages to her Instagram story with the caption, ‚ÄúLove me or hate me, I compete hard for 60 mins, but no one deserves this.‚Äù The abusive messages were immediately condemned by fans across social media and the Giants released a statement on their website.

‚ÄúBehaviour like this is completely unacceptable and our athletes deserve better,‚Äù said general manager Tim Underwood. ‚ÄúJo is an experienced player who will no doubt move on quickly like the champion she is, but she‚Äôs done the right thing by calling this incident out. Not every athlete has the tools to deal with such vitriol and abuse like this can do serious damage to the mental wellbeing of athletes.‚Äù

Harten‚Äôs decision to reveal the extent of the abuse she was facing was applauded by players and fans, with former Australian Diamonds captain Liz Ellis sharing the abuse she was subjected to after commenting on NRL player Toby Rudolph‚Äôs post-match interview in March. An NRL fan who took issue with Ellis‚Äôs stance wrote: ‚ÄúHope your husband flogs you tonight for your comments it‚Äôs very much warranted.‚Äù

Related: Netball‚Äôs not a tough sport? Players let game do talking in brutal riposte | Erin Delahunty

Male athletes have to deal with plenty of online abuse of their own, but there is a particular level of abuse reserved for female athletes, which is often based on appearance, sexuality or the perception that they need to be kept in line by the men in their lives. While online abuse is broadly unacceptable, this gendered element, alongside the compounding factor of female athletes being paid at much lower levels than their male counterparts, is particularly concerning.

In the end it all comes down to this ‚Äì is it worth it? Is the increased public profile, the engagement with fans and the community spirit of the sport enough to make up for this abuse? That is a question that each individual needs to answer for themselves. Harten took to Instagram again the following day to thank fans for the outpouring of support she received after posting the abuse and Ellis has also been inundated with positive replies from the community known as ‚ÄòNetball Twitter‚Äô.

As author Madeleine L‚ÄôEngle once mused, ‚ÄúMaybe you have to know the darkness before you can appreciate the light.‚Äù In times of adversity, communities come together and fight. For all its ills, social media has the power to stoke the fires of revolution and with that comes powerful, positive change.

Harten returned to her hotel room to discover a series of hateful, abusive messages sent to her on Instagram, urging her to ‚Äúdie‚Äù and ‚Äúrot in hell‚Äù and calling her an ‚Äúugly bitch‚Äù. Harten posted the messages to her Instagram story with the caption, ‚ÄúLove me or hate me, I compete hard for 60 mins, but no one deserves this.‚Äù The abusive messages were immediately condemned by fans across social media and the Giants released a statement on their website. ‚ÄúBehaviour like this is completely unacceptable and our athletes deserve better,‚Äù said general manager Tim Underwood. ‚ÄúJo is an experienced player who will no doubt move on quickly like the champion she is, but she‚Äôs done the right thing by calling this incident out. Not every athlete has the tools to deal with such vitriol and abuse like this can do serious damage to the mental wellbeing of athletes.‚Äù Harten‚Äôs decision to reveal the extent of the abuse she was facing was applauded by players and fans, with former Australian Diamonds captain Liz Ellis sharing the abuse she was subjected to after commenting on NRL player Toby Rudolph‚Äôs post-match interview in March. An NRL fan who took issue with Ellis‚Äôs stance wrote: ‚ÄúHope your husband flogs you tonight for your comments it‚Äôs very much warranted.‚Äù Male athletes have to deal with plenty of online abuse of their own, but there is a particular level of abuse reserved for female athletes, which is often based on appearance, sexuality or the perception that they need to be kept in line by the men in their lives. While online abuse is broadly unacceptable, this gendered element, alongside the compounding factor of female athletes being paid at much lower levels than their male counterparts, is particularly concerning. In the end it all comes down to this ‚Äì is it worth it? Is the increased public profile, the engagement with fans and the community spirit of the sport enough to make up for this abuse? That is a question that each individual needs to answer for themselves. Harten took to Instagram again the following day to thank fans for the outpouring of support she received after posting the abuse and Ellis has also been inundated with positive replies from the community known as ‚ÄòNetball Twitter‚Äô. As author Madeleine L‚ÄôEngle once mused, ‚ÄúMaybe you have to know the darkness before you can appreciate the light.‚Äù In times of adversity, communities come together and fight. For all its ills, social media has the power to stoke the fires of revolution and with that comes powerful, positive change.

headline: Peter V‚Äôlandys will live and die calling NRL shots from on high
standfirst: With little apparent regard for player power the ARL Commission chairman is stirring a revolt with his iron fist approach on high hits
trailText: With little apparent regard for player power the ARL Commission chairman is stirring a revolt with his iron fist approach on high hits
body:
It was 1995 and rapacious merchants roamed the land, cashed-up soldiers of the Super League war seeking to plunder rugby union‚Äôs best players. The greater game, long pillaged by the pros, bit the bullet and declared itself professional.

Rupert Murdoch decided to buy in, his great vulture wings spawning a Super Rugby club out of the ACT Rugby Union. In Canberra a rag-tag band of outcasts, journeymen and locals invented themselves.

Or so they thought. For while the players were tossing up names for the new club-franchise ‚Äì Dingoes, Chargers and the like ‚Äì inaugural coach Rod Macqueen had already decided that it would be Brumbies. He just hadn‚Äôt told anybody. Sure, he was all for ‚Äúplayer power‚Äù and said as much often. And yes, the players did create, innovate and invent the Brumbies‚Äô brand of fun-running rugby.

Related: State of Origin series opener moved to Townsville amid Covid outbreak in Melbourne

But when it came to the name of the club, the players would later concede that Brumbies was a lock all along because MacQueen decided that it would be. The man‚Äôs great trick had been to make the players believe they had a say.

ARL Commission chief Peter V‚Äôlandys, for all his talents, appears not to have quite mastered the same trick. And now, according to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald, leading players have been mulling methods for removing V‚Äôlandys from his position.

And yet for all the noise around the disaffection players apparently have for the league‚Äôs strict crackdown on high tackles, the major carp from players, their union and some in the press appears to be that players were not consulted about it. That V‚Äôlandys, in trademark style, just bunged in the rule without asking them.

‚ÄúThis is about working through a process and ensuring we have a genuine and respectful opportunity to have dialogue in advance of any [suggested] changes,‚Äù Rugby League Players Association chief Clint Newton told Triple M radio.

Luke Keary spoke with less corporate finesse on SEN. ‚ÄúYou send numerous amounts of people off the field and just ruin games of football just to prove a point,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere are so many better ways they could have gone about it.

‚ÄúInvolving coaches, players, referees, stakeholders of the game. Getting them together and explaining this is what we‚Äôre doing and this is how we‚Äôre going to stop it. I don‚Äôt think you can just walk out there and tell the refs to start sending players off and put the quality of the game at risk.‚Äù

Keary admitted that ‚Äúin principle, what they‚Äôre trying to do is right‚Äù. He then added: ‚ÄúThe way they‚Äôve gone about it is so wrong it‚Äôs not funny.‚Äù

Keary, Newton and almost everyone agrees ‚Äì for only sociopaths could not ‚Äì that it is very important to protect players‚Äô heads. It is of course fair they question how head office has gone about it. Yet the rub is this: they offer no alternatives. They just know they don‚Äôt like it.

Rugby league people do not appear to be pondering whether the league‚Äôs way ‚Äì penalise, report, sin bin and/or send off players for every high tackle ‚Äì is the only way to lessen the number of incidents of players tackling the head. Everyone agrees they want players‚Äô heads protected, but how else can that be done?

Yes, you can tinker around the edges with five-minute sin bins or send-offs in which the player can be replaced after 10 or 20 minutes. Greater fines? It‚Äôs hard to see the players agreeing with that. It‚Äôs also hard to see fines stopping high shots, though perhaps in a consultative, respectful discussion forum they could have worked a few things out.

Or maybe they would have held lengthy talks and come up with a compromise that didn‚Äôt actually ‚Äì and quite ironically ‚Äì adequately protect the very players‚Äô own precious heads.

Manly Sea Eagles captain Daly Cherry-Evans is one who had been critical of V‚Äôlandys‚Äô lack of consultation with players. ‚ÄúNaturally I respect what Daly Cherry-Evans says,‚Äù V‚Äôlandys told AAP. ‚ÄúBut for me it was an urgent matter that needed addressing. It was our strategy as a commission since February. Everyone knew we would be addressing the head injury matter. When it‚Äôs a safety matter I don‚Äôt know why anyone wouldn‚Äôt welcome that someone is looking at the safety of [players].‚Äù

V‚Äôlandys added that the ‚Äúirony of the whole situation is I am only looking after their best interests‚Äù. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done all this ‚Äì which has put stress in my life ‚Äì to help them. Not to hurt them,‚Äù he said.

Rugby league, in a very rugby league way, is eating its own head. Players want to be consulted. V‚Äôlandys wants to get things done. The media is keeping score who‚Äôs winning. (Answer: AFL.)

The benign dictatorship model worked for V‚Äôlandys in unprecedented Covid times and he was forgiven the crash-through approach. Today, not so much.

Yet he remains unapologetic. ‚ÄúWhen it comes to safety, there is no need to consult,‚Äù he told the Sydney Morning Herald. ‚ÄúIf a pedestrian is going to be hit by a car, you stop it from happening now. You don‚Äôt wait until they‚Äôve been hit and then try to do something.‚Äù

V‚Äôlandys appears to have no other agenda than to protect players‚Äô heads. He‚Äôs doing it for for the league, for young players, for players who seem to need protection from themselves. Ultimately he‚Äôs in charge. And ultimately he is where the buck stops. He‚Äôll live and die on his decisions. And he‚Äôll do it without input from those who don‚Äôt have alternatives to the status quo.

headline: Teaching consent to toddlers: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm happy we‚Äôre starting to have this conversation‚Äô
standfirst: New Australian kids‚Äô books are helping parents and carers introduce children to the concept of boundaries and bodily autonomy
trailText: New Australian kids‚Äô books are helping parents and carers introduce children to the concept of boundaries and bodily autonomy
body:
When Australian author and illustrator Sophie Beer started writing her latest book about consent ‚Äì a board book pitched for the one-to-three-year-old reader ‚Äì the conversation was already changing.

‚ÄúThis was at the beginning of the pandemic, and society was suddenly a lot more cognisant of greetings and interpersonal consent,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSuddenly, shaking hands and hugging hello was risky and we had to get creative with awkwardly waving and elbow-bumping instead. All these new greetings [became] a vehicle for us to discuss preference of personal boundaries with kids.‚Äù

Related: Why are Australian children's books suddenly so political?

Illustrated in her bright, electric style, How to Say Hello offers children a variety of greetings to choose from, from fist bumps to smiles; from special dances to peeks out from between a parent‚Äôs legs. Ultimately, she writes, ‚Äúthere are so many ways to say hello!‚Äù with the book delivering an inclusive message of empowerment about making your own choices, and respecting those of others.

Board books on bodily autonomy and consent aren‚Äôt common ‚Äì but when it comes to picture books, Beer recommends Emily Neilson‚Äôs Can I Give You a Squish (‚Äúgorgeous and playful‚Äù) and Sharee Miller‚Äôs Don‚Äôt Touch My Hair! As children grow older and more curious, there are even more resources, including the ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù Welcome to Consent! by Yumi Stynes and Dr Melissa Kang.

Kang explains that, as a society, we‚Äôre becoming more literate on the issue of consent. ‚ÄúYoung people themselves are demanding change ‚Äì to education, to the law, to society‚Äôs attitudes to women and to power imbalances,‚Äù she says. And in a post-MeToo world, books are one of many ways to bring the issue to younger children.

‚ÄúThe younger the child, the more a parent or carer needs to physically touch a child in order to care for them ‚Äì but there are many opportunities to frame these actions into consent-nurturing interactions,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt is possible to educate children about their bodies, feelings, thoughts, actions and values ‚Äì which are the basics of consent.‚Äù

Beer believes that learning social boundaries and how to enforce them can never be taught too young. She also thinks it‚Äôs important to teach kids that people can communicate differently and might accept greetings differently: differences in sensory processing and socialisation can make hugs uncomfortable for some, for example.

‚ÄúChildren‚Äôs individual consent is just as important as teenagers‚Äô or adults‚Äô,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúToo often, a child may feel uncomfortable hugging an unfamiliar relative hello, yet they are ordered to for the sake of politeness.

‚ÄúBeing respectful of differences in personal boundaries is a kindness we can afford to anyone, young or old,‚Äù she continues. ‚Äú[Even now], I very often put up with behaviour from people I was uncomfortable with just for the sake of social politeness as a young woman.‚Äù

Sex educator and researcher Deanne Carson of Body Safety Australia, says that while discussing consent with preverbal or nonverbal children (like the audience of How to Say Hello) might be challenging, there are ways to teach bodily autonomy, such as by naming body parts, asking questions (‚Äúwould you like me to help you get dressed?‚Äù), and explaining to a child why an adult might need to help a child be safe ‚Äì like getting them into a car seat or giving first aid.

‚ÄúAll of this connects with the child, and develops their understanding of their body, helping children to be as empowered as they can be,‚Äù says Carson. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy we‚Äôre starting to have this conversation.‚Äù

How To Say Hello is the latest in Beer‚Äôs series of board books which feature a range of family structures, races and disabilities ‚Äì including Love Makes a Family, Change Starts with Us and Kindness Makes Us Strong. ‚ÄúWith this series, I‚Äôve aspired to create a colourful, cosy world of kindness and inclusivity,‚Äù Beer says.

‚ÄúThis last year of the pandemic has also been a strange time of global isolation, so saying hello and togetherness seems a lovely ambition.‚Äù

  • How to Say Hello by Sophie Beer and Welcome to Consent! by Yumi Stynes and Dr Melissa Kang are both out in Australia through Hardie Grant

headline: US secretary of state warns Pacific leaders about ‚Äòcoercion‚Äô in veiled swipe at China
standfirst: Antony Blinken takes a shot at Beijing‚Äôs growing influence with rallying call for ‚Äòinternational rules-based order‚Äô
trailText: Antony Blinken takes a shot at Beijing‚Äôs growing influence with rallying call for ‚Äòinternational rules-based order‚Äô
body:
The US secretary of state has warned leaders of Pacific countries about ‚Äúthreats to the rules-based international order‚Äù and ‚Äúeconomic coercion‚Äù, in what appears to be a veiled swipe at China‚Äôs growing influence in the region.

Antony Blinken was addressing leaders and their delegates from 11 Pacific countries and territories including Fiji, Solomon Islands, Cook Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, French Polynesia, Palau and Marshall Islands as part of the Pacific Islands Conference of Leaders, which is held in Hawaii.

Related: The $3bn bargain: how China dominates Pacific mining, logging and fishing

Blinken reiterated US support for Pacific island nations as they face the ‚Äúshared challenges that we have to confront together‚Äù, including Covid-19 and the climate crisis. He also appeared to make a criticism of Australia‚Äôs action on the climate crisis, calling for ‚Äúall countries, particularly the biggest emitters, to swiftly and dramatically reduce emissions.‚Äù

But the main focus of his televised address was China‚Äôs growing influence in the region.

‚ÄúEconomic coercion across the region is on the rise. The US is all for more development and investment in the islands, but that investment should adhere to international standards for environmentally and socially sustainable development and should be pursued transparently, with public consultation,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd every country, no matter its size, should always be able to make choices without fear of retribution.‚Äù

Jonathan Pryke, director of the Lowy Institute‚Äôs Pacific Islands Program in Australia, said it was ‚Äúpretty obvious‚Äù who Blinken had in his sights during the speech.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs only one country that is engaging in the Pacific in a big way in the past few decades that isn‚Äôt part of the traditional club and that is China,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very thinly veiled who he is talking about when he‚Äôs talking about economic coercion.‚Äù

China has deepened its connections with governments across the Pacific in the last few decades, amid a soft power push that sees it rivalling the influence of Australia.

China has engaged in significant lending to Pacific countries, as well as paying for massive infrastructure projects. A report in 2018 found that Papua New Guinea, the largest country in the Pacific Islands with a population of roughly nine million, had been accepting unaffordable Chinese loans, and in 2019, Papua New Guinea asked China to refinance its entire government debt, a request that marked a ‚Äúsignificant shift‚Äù in regional politics, according to Pacific analysts.

Related: ‚ÄòThey failed us‚Äô: how mining and logging devastated a Pacific island in a decade

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fully legitimate for China to be operating in the Pacific and there are legitimate concerns about the way China is operating in the Pacific as well,‚Äù said Pryke. ‚ÄúI do think we underestimate the agency of Pacific nations and their ability to make decisions ‚Ä¶ Pacific islands have wisened up to China.‚Äù

Pryke also said that it was ‚Äúa bit rich‚Äù for the US to be warning Pacific nations about China‚Äôs influence given the country‚Äôs almost nonexistent diplomatic presence in many Pacific countries.

‚ÄúThey really have such a marginal footprint, it‚Äôs one thing to say all these things about ‚Äòbe careful, we need to stop this malign influence in your countries‚Äô, but what are the alternatives you‚Äôre providing?‚Äù

Blinken‚Äôs address was part of the Pacific Islands Conference of Leaders, and was attended by leaders or delegates from 11 countries or territories, but representatives from a significant number of countries, including Papua New Guinea, Tonga, Vanuatu, Kiribati, Tuvalu and Samoa did not attend.

By contrast, last week, China held a virtual China-Pacific island discussion which was attended by senior representatives from the governments of most countries, including the prime ministers of Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu, the president of the Federated States of Micronesia, the premier of Niue and Fiji‚Äôs defence minister.

In his address, Blinken also affirmed the United States‚Äô commitment to taking action on the climate crisis, which he said posed a ‚Äúthreat that is existential for the islands‚Äù.

‚ÄúCountries must make and beat ambitious commitments. The US is leading by example on this front. Biden has set out targets to reduce emissions by at least half by 2030,‚Äù Blinken said.

Dr Wesley Morgan, research fellow at Griffith Asia Institute, said it was ‚Äúentirely possible‚Äù that Blinken had Canberra in mind when he made these comments.

‚ÄúThey are also taking a swipe at Australia and want to see action on climate,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe Pacific has for decades now wanted Australia to take strong action on climate change and now they see an ally in the White House and they also see an ally in Downing Street. The Pacific used to be seen as ‚Äòout there‚Äô in calling for an end to coal, but now it‚Äôs Australia that is a long way out there ‚Ä¶ the Pacific has all these global allies now and Australia is very isolated on climate.‚Äù

A report in 2018 found that Papua New Guinea, the largest country in the Pacific Islands with a population of roughly nine million, had been accepting unaffordable Chinese loans, and in 2019, Papua New Guinea asked China to refinance its entire government debt, a request that marked a ‚Äúsignificant shift‚Äù in regional politics, according to Pacific analysts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fully legitimate for China to be operating in the Pacific and there are legitimate concerns about the way China is operating in the Pacific as well,‚Äù said Pryke. ‚ÄúI do think we underestimate the agency of Pacific nations and their ability to make decisions ‚Ä¶ Pacific islands have wisened up to China.‚Äù Pryke also said that it was ‚Äúa bit rich‚Äù for the US to be warning Pacific nations about China‚Äôs influence given the country‚Äôs almost nonexistent diplomatic presence in many Pacific countries. ‚ÄúThey really have such a marginal footprint, it‚Äôs one thing to say all these things about ‚Äòbe careful, we need to stop this malign influence in your countries‚Äô, but what are the alternatives you‚Äôre providing?‚Äù Blinken‚Äôs address was part of the Pacific Islands Conference of Leaders, and was attended by leaders or delegates from 11 countries or territories, but representatives from a significant number of countries, including Papua New Guinea, Tonga, Vanuatu, Kiribati, Tuvalu and Samoa did not attend. By contrast, last week, China held a virtual China-Pacific island discussion which was attended by senior representatives from the governments of most countries, including the prime ministers of Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu, the president of the Federated States of Micronesia, the premier of Niue and Fiji‚Äôs defence minister. In his address, Blinken also affirmed the United States‚Äô commitment to taking action on the climate crisis, which he said posed a ‚Äúthreat that is existential for the islands‚Äù. ‚ÄúCountries must make and beat ambitious commitments. The US is leading by example on this front. Biden has set out targets to reduce emissions by at least half by 2030,‚Äù Blinken said. Dr Wesley Morgan, research fellow at Griffith Asia Institute, said it was ‚Äúentirely possible‚Äù that Blinken had Canberra in mind when he made these comments. ‚ÄúThey are also taking a swipe at Australia and want to see action on climate,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe Pacific has for decades now wanted Australia to take strong action on climate change and now they see an ally in the White House and they also see an ally in Downing Street. The Pacific used to be seen as ‚Äòout there‚Äô in calling for an end to coal, but now it‚Äôs Australia that is a long way out there ‚Ä¶ the Pacific has all these global allies now and Australia is very isolated on climate.‚Äù

headline: Covid Victoria lockdown restrictions: Melbourne and regional Vic new coronavirus rules explained
standfirst:
New Victorian Covid-19 restrictions have been announced in response to a growing number of cases in the Melbourne coronavirus outbreak. Can you leave home? Is mask-wearing compulsory? Are schools closed? Is travelling permitted? What is the 10km radius for? Here are the new rules

  • Follow LIVE Covid updates on Wednesday
  • Victoria Covid case alerts and list of public exposure sites
  • Covid vaccine rollout numbers: tracking vaccination progress
  • Download the free Guardian app
trailText: New Victorian Covid-19 restrictions have been announced in response to a growing number of cases in the Melbourne coronavirus outbreak. Can you leave home? Is mask-wearing compulsory? Are schools closed? Is travelling permitted? What is the 10km radius for? Here are the new rules
body:
Victoria has extended its seven-day ‚Äúcircuit-breaker lockdown‚Äù to 14 days in response to the growing Covid cluster in Melbourne‚Äôs northern suburbs.

The initial seven-day lockdown applied to the entire state until Thursday 3 June, however on Wednesday 2 June, with over 350 exposure sites, the Victorian government announced the lockdown would be extended for greater Melbourne, with some small changes, until 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.

The following rules apply from 11.59pm Thursday 3 June to greater Melbourne and regional Victoria.

When can I leave my house?

You cannot leave your home unless it is for one of five approved reasons.

The reasons are: shopping; authorised work or education; exercise; caregiving, compassionate and medical reasons; and to get vaccinated.

Those first four reasons are the same as previous lockdowns, and the fifth reason ‚Äì to get vaccinated ‚Äì is new.

People in regional Victoria can leave home for any reason.

How far can I travel from home?

For shopping and exercise, you need to stay within a 10km radius of your home.

Regional Victorians have no restrictions on how far they can travel within regional Victoria.

What are the rules for exercise?

There is a two-hour limit on exercise, and can only be with one other person, and you must stay within a 10km radius of your home.

What are the rules for wearing face masks?

Masks must be worn everywhere except for in your home. This includes both indoor places and outdoor areas ‚Äì unless you have a medical exemption.

In regional Victoria, the same rules apply, except you do not have to wear your mask outdoors unless 1.5m of physical distancing cannot be maintained.

Can I have visitors to my house?

No visitors are allowed to your home, other than an intimate partner. People who live alone will be able to form a ‚Äúsingle bubble‚Äù. If you live alone, you can make a bubble with another person, who can visit you.

The same rule applies for both Melbourne and regional Victoria.

Can I travel interstate?

Each state and territory is updating guidance on travel rules individually:

  • Queensland

  • New South Wales

  • South Australia

  • Western Australia

  • Tasmania

  • Australian Capital Territory

  • Northern Territory

What about public gatherings?

Public gatherings are not allowed in Melbourne.

In regional Victoria, up to 10 people can hold public gatherings.

What is happening with schools?

Year 11 and 12 students and other students enrolled in unit 3 and 4 VCE studies will be allowed to return to school in Melbourne.

Onsite learning is also allowed for vulnerable children or children of authorised workers.

Remote learning for everyone else in Melbourne.

Childcare centres and kindergartens are still open.

In regional Victoria face-to-face learning returns for all year levels.

Can I dine in at a restaurant or cafe?

Not in Melbourne. Restaurants, cafes and pubs will be open for takeaway only.

In regional Victoria, it is open for seated service only, with a maximum patron cap of 50 people, group sizes of a maximum of 10 people and density quotient of one person per 4 sq metre.

Are the shops open?

In Melbourne, essential retail, such as supermarkets, petrol, pharmacies, bottle shops and banks, will be open. But other shops will be open only for click and collect.

In regional Victoria, retail can open with a density quotient of one person per 4 sq metres.

Across Victoria all venues are now required to make people sign in to the Service Vic QR code app.

What about weddings, funerals and religious services?

In Melbourne, only 10 people will be allowed to attend funerals in person. No weddings are allowed unless for end of life or deportation reasons. No religious activities are allowed in person beyond five people.

In regional Victoria, weddings can have no more than two people, including the two being married, the celebrant, and two witnesses. Funerals can have no more than 50 people, but children under 12 months do not count in this cap.

What about aged care and hospitals?

Across Victoria, no visitors are allowed at aged care facilities except for limited reasons. There will be no visitors to hospitals allowed except for end of life, if you‚Äôre a partner during the birth of your child, or a parent accompanying a child.

Can I go and get vaccinated?

Getting vaccinated is one of the reasons people who are eligible to receive the jab can leave home. The Victorian government has expanded the eligibility to include those aged between 40-49 for state-operated vaccination sites. People in this category can now call the hotline on 1800 675 398 to book an appointment.

What about heading back to the office?

In Melbourne if people can work from home they must work from home.

In regional Victoria, if people can work from home they must work from home, but workplaces can have up to 50% of staff in the office, or maximum 20 people, whichever is greater.

  • Due to the unprecedented and ongoing nature of the coronavirus outbreak, this article is regularly updated to ensure it reflects the current situation at the date of publication. Any significant corrections made to this or previous versions of the article will continue to be footnoted in line with Guardian editorial policy.

headline: ‚ÄòZero‚Äô: how the UK papers covered a day without a single reported Covid death
standfirst:
All eyes now turn to whether this makes an easing of England‚Äôs Covid measures on 21 June more likely

  • See all our coronavirus coverage
trailText: All eyes now turn to whether this makes an easing of England‚Äôs Covid measures on 21 June more likely
body:
Good news is broadcast across Wednesday‚Äôs front pages, as editors seize a rare opportunity to report on hope in the battle against the coronavirus.

Many papers suggest that the first day without a single Covid death for 10 months means the complete easing of lockdown restrictions will go ahead in England as planned on 21 June.

The Daily Express says simply ‚ÄúZero‚Äù in large letters, adding that ‚Äúhopes have been boosted for Freedom Day go-ahead‚Äù.

The Daily Mirror takes a similar tack with the headline ‚ÄúZero Covid deaths in the UK‚Äù but warns in its story that thousands of fresh daily cases have led to calls to delay the easing of restrictions.

The Daily Telegraph says Boris Johnson is now under pressure to lift restrictions on 21 June. It notes with concern the move by Nicola Sturgeon to slow an easing of Covid measures in parts of Scotland. Leader writer Philip Johnston cites the example of Melbourne to argue against trying to eliminate Covid for fear of creating a ‚Äúperpetual to-ing and fro-ing‚Äù out of restrictions. (The Australian state of Victoria has been in a week-long lockdown to tackle a fast-spreading outbreak ‚Äì you can read more here.)

The Guardian marks the good news across the bottom of its front page, but focuses on concerns the ¬£1.4bn programme to help children catch up at school post-Covid is not enough.

The Times also features concerns about the education package but gives the zero deaths story the biggest treatment. ‚ÄúFresh hope for June 21 as deaths fall to zero‚Äù it says, but does note that this may just be a blip as a result of the bank holiday weekend.

The Daily Mail has a two-part headline: ‚ÄúZero deaths .. nothing to fear from freedom‚Äù. It reports the existence of ‚Äúan insidious campaign‚Äù to delay the easing of restrictions and makes clear to Johnson that he should resist such calls.

The i carries health secretary Matt Hancock‚Äôs joy that the vaccination programme appears to be working, and his warning for people to keep following the rules. ‚ÄúHopes rise for 21 June after zero UK deaths‚Äù is the headline. It also includes the line that the UK is to buy an AstraZeneca vaccine adapted to tackle the Beta variant (the one first found in South Africa).

Metro goes straight with ‚ÄúNot a single Covid death in UK‚Äù but reports a doubling of daily cases in the space of a month, and Sturgeon‚Äôs decision to slow the easing of Covid measures.

In Scotland, the Daily Record cannot resist an 80s band reference with ‚ÄúTiers for beers‚Äù as it reports that Glaswegians will be permitted to drink inside from Saturday as part of a move to level 2 restrictions.

The Scotsman reports on business frustration after Scotland moves ‚Äúfrom lockdown to slowdown‚Äù, in reference to Sturgeon‚Äôs decisions.

headline: Anthony Albanese sends mixed signals on fossil fuels as Labor wrestles over climate policy
standfirst: Albanese will use speech to Minerals Council of Australia to reassure mining companies as well as warn that the Coalition are risking jobs by opposing renewables
trailText: Albanese will use speech to Minerals Council of Australia to reassure mining companies as well as warn that the Coalition are risking jobs by opposing renewables
body:
Anthony Albanese will accuse the Morrison government of putting Australian jobs and exports at risk by its opposition to renewable energy and its bellicose rhetoric on China.

The Labor leader will use a speech to the Minerals Council of Australia to reassure mining companies that the opposition supports the continuing export of fossil fuels.

But Albanese will also signal Labor‚Äôs intention to hasten the shift to the new energy economy because the world is moving to a low-carbon future, and ‚Äúmarkets change‚Äù.

Albanese‚Äôs speech comes as Labor continues to wrestle over the direction of its climate and energy policy. During Tuesday‚Äôs regular meeting of the caucus, the Victorian MPs Ged Kearney and Libby Coker expressed concern about new gas development in the Beetaloo basin during a debate triggered by a disallowance motion proposed by the independent Zali Steggall.

Related: After two years with Anthony Albanese at the helm, Labor feels Scott Morrison can be beaten | Katharine Murphy

Steggall‚Äôs motion, which has support in the caucus, seeks to halt new gas development in the Northern Territory. But Labor has resolved to reject the proposed disallowance, and a number of MPs, including Joel Fitzgibbon and Bill Shorten, argued that was the correct call because Labor supported the use of gas as a transition fuel.

Fitzgibbon has been on a public crusade since Labor‚Äôs election loss in 2019, claiming the party has lost touch with its blue-collar base, allowing the Coalition to portray itself as a better friend to workers due to its support for traditional extractive industries.

Albanese will declare in Wednesday‚Äôs speech to the Minerals Council that the Morrison government has distorted ‚Äúinvestment decisions while undermining job-creating ventures that will lower power prices‚Äù through its opposition to renewable energy.

The Labor leader cites the resources minister, Keith Pitt, vetoing a recommendation from the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility board to invest in a windfarm south of Cairns ‚Äúthat would have created 250 jobs and helped reduce power prices ‚Ä¶ leaving the Labor government in Queensland to step in to fill the gap‚Äù.

Channelling concerns in the resources sector about the damaging economic impact of the trade dispute between Canberra and Beijing, Albanese will also chip the government for its handling of the relationship with Beijing, which he notes must be of ‚Äúreal concern‚Äù to members of the Minerals Council and other exporters.

‚ÄúScott Morrison has no long-term strategy to deal with a changing China that is pressing its interests more assertively, while finding areas of potential cooperation, including on trade, that are in both our countries‚Äô interests,‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúMr Morrison is making the grave error of prioritising his domestic political interests over Australia‚Äôs national interests.‚Äù

Albanese cites comments from the defence minister, Peter Dutton, and the home affairs department secretary Michael Pezzullo‚Äôs warnings about the drums of war as forays that might ‚Äúinflame nationalistic sentiments‚Äù but harm Australia‚Äôs interests.

‚ÄúAustralian needs more strategy and less politics when it comes to managing our differences with China.‚Äù

Albanese argues that despite eight years in office the Coalition lacks a legacy of economic reform, accusing it of spending $100bn in the latest budget with no plan to pay back net debt of $1tn. ‚ÄúThis budget is a debt sentence for Australia,‚Äù he says.

He says Labor will help encourage jobs growth, lower power prices and higher-end manufacturing through its $20bn rewiring the nation policy and $15bn national reconstruction fund.

The policies establish off-budget funds to invest in Australia‚Äôs electricity transmission network and manufacturing, in the same way the Clean Energy Finance Corporation invests in renewables.

Albanese argues that lower energy costs combined with increased automation provide an opportunity to reverse the long-term decline of Australian manufacturing.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no longer good enough to ship raw materials to overseas markets then buy back manufactured goods at a premium. We can do better.‚Äù

Nevertheless, Albanese acknowledges that Australia ‚Äúwill continue to export‚Äù its current top resources: iron ore, liquefied natural gas, gold, metallurgical and thermal coal.

‚ÄúBut as everyone here knows, markets change,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAs the world moves to a low-carbon future, demand for some resources will decline. But there will be strong demand for other resources, particularly those needed for growth sectors like electric vehicles and batteries.‚Äù

Albanese notes that Australia also has a ‚Äúbright future‚Äù exporting other resources including aluminium, lithium, copper, cobalt, nickel and rare earths.
